title: 106_hr2309
content: The "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Special rules apply to group health plans. Section 503 of ERISA is amended to include special rules for group health plans, requiring claims procedures to notify participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to a utilization review agent and an independent review organization. The amendment to Section 503 of ERISA includes rules for group health plans, such as notifying participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to an independent review organization. This includes procedures for immediate review for life-threatening conditions and fair, de novo determinations of medical necessity. The amendment to Section 503 of ERISA allows participants to appeal denied benefits to a utilization review agent. The procedures for appeals must be reasonable and include the option to appeal orally or in writing. The agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents. The appeal process to a utilization review agent includes submitting necessary documents, receiving a one-page appeal form for oral appeals, and having appeal decisions made by a physician. If the appeal is denied, a health care provider in the same specialty can review the case upon request within 10 working days. The expedited appeal procedure for emergency care denials, life-threatening conditions, and denials of continued stays for hospitalized patients must be completed within one working day from the receipt of all necessary information. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter explaining the resolution of the appeal, including specific reasons and clinical basis, within 30 days of receiving the appeal. The review agent receives the appeal for an independent review of adverse determinations by an independent review organization, ensuring timely responses, confidentiality of medical records, and independence in the review process. The independent review organization ensures the independence of healthcare providers making review determinations and provides timely notice of results to participants. Utilization review agents must provide necessary information to the independent review organization within 3 business days of receiving a request for review. The independent review organization requires relevant medical records, documents used in the determination, clinical basis for denial, information supporting the appeal, and a list of physicians involved. The independent review organization needs medical records from physicians involved in the care of the participant. Timelines for determinations by the organization are set at 15 days after receiving necessary information or 20 days after receiving the appeal. The independent review organization must make a determination for a life-threatening condition within 5 days of receiving necessary information or 8 days after receiving the request. To be certified as an independent review organization, an organization must submit an annual application to the Secretary, including details like stockholders and business type. The annual application for certification as an independent review organization must include details such as affiliated corporations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, biographical information of directors and executives, and relationships with health insurance providers. The annual application for certification as an independent review organization must include details such as affiliated corporations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, biographical information of directors and executives, relationships with health insurance providers, and the anticipated percentage of revenues from reviews conducted under this subsection. Additionally, it should provide a description of the areas of expertise of the health care professionals involved. The independent review organization must include details such as affiliated corporations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, biographical information of directors and executives, relationships with health insurance providers, and the anticipated percentage of revenues from reviews. The expertise of health care professionals making review determinations is crucial. The determination by the independent review organization is final and binding on the plan, subject to possible vacation or modification by a court. An independent review organization conducting reviews under this section must be independent and not owned or controlled by a payor. The organization is not liable for damages resulting from its determinations. Definitions include 'adverse determination' as a decision by a group health plan or utilization review agent regarding healthcare services for a participant. The term 'health care provider' refers to individuals or entities delivering health care services in a State, required to be licensed or certified by State law. A 'life-threatening condition' is defined as a serious medical condition. A 'life-threatening condition' is a disease or medical condition where death or serious bodily injury is likely without interruption. A 'payor' includes insurers, preferred provider organizations, self-insurance plans, and entities providing health benefits. A 'utilization review agent' conducts reviews for employers with covered employees. The term 'working day' is defined as a weekday excluding legal holidays for employers, payors, and administrators under a group health plan.
